questions.text: Modified biophysical profile consists of:
questions.solution:
The Modified Biophysical Profile (MBPP) is used to assess fetal well-being by combining two components:

a. AFI & NST

Explanation.

Components of MBPP:

  1. Non-Stress Test (NST):
    • Purpose: Measures fetal heart rate response to fetal movements.
    • Procedure: The mother is connected to a fetal heart rate monitor to track the fetal heart rate over time, usually for 20-40 minutes. A reactive NST shows at least two accelerations of the fetal heart rate (at least 15 beats per minute above the baseline) in a 20-minute period.
  2. Amniotic Fluid Index (AFI):
    • Purpose: Assesses the amount of amniotic fluid, which can be an indicator of fetal health and well-being.
    • Procedure: AFI is determined through a transabdominal ultrasound, where the uterus is divided into four quadrants, and the deepest vertical pocket of amniotic fluid in each quadrant is measured and summed.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

The MBPP is a valuable tool for evaluating fetal health in a more streamlined manner, focusing on the NST and AFI to provide essential information on fetal well-being.

questions.text: Single best fetal biometric parameter which reflects nutritional status of the fetus:
questions.solution:
Abdominal Circumference (AC) is the single best fetal biometric parameter for assessing the nutritional status of the fetus. This measurement reflects the fetal growth and can be indicative of the fetal liver size, which is influenced by the nutritional status and overall health of the fetus.

  • Option a) Biparietal Diameter (BPD) and Option b) Head Circumference (HC) are useful in assessing fetal growth but are more indicative of head size rather than overall nutritional status.
  • Option d) Femur Length (FL) helps evaluate skeletal growth but is less sensitive to changes in nutritional status compared to abdominal circumference.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

  • Direct Measurement: AC provides a direct measurement of the fetal abdomen, where the liver, which reflects glycogen storage and overall growth, is located.
  • Growth Restriction Indicator: In cases of intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR), the abdominal circumference is often disproportionately smaller compared to other measurements like head circumference, making it a crucial parameter in identifying growth abnormalities.

Thus, abdominal circumference is the most reliable parameter for assessing fetal nutritional status.

choices.text: It is a tool for fetal monitoring in low-risk pregnancies
Auscultation of the fetal heart rate (FHR) should be for 1 full minute soon after a contraction
IA should be done every 15 minutes in the first stage and every 5 minutes in the second stage in low risk pregnancies
Listen for 15 seconds & multiply by 4 to get FHR in beats/min

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct regarding intermittent auscultation (IA), except:
questions.solution:
The correct method is to listen to the FHR for 1 full minute to obtain an accurate reading.

Intermittent Auscultation (IA) is a method used to monitor the fetal heart rate (FHR) during labor, particularly in low-risk pregnancies, to detect any signs of fetal distress.

Option a) It is a tool for fetal monitoring in low-risk pregnancies: Correct. IA is generally used for low-risk pregnancies to monitor the fetal heart rate and ensure the fetus is not experiencing distress.

Option b) Auscultation of the fetal heart rate (FHR) should be for 1 full minute soon after a contraction: Correct. To accurately assess the FHR, it should be listened to for 1 full minute, particularly after a contraction to identify any changes or patterns.

Option c) IA should be done every 15 minutes in the first stage and every 5 minutes in the second stage in low-risk pregnancies: Correct. The frequency of IA is typically every 15 minutes in the first stage of labor and every 5 minutes in the second stage for low-risk pregnancies.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

  • If only 15 seconds of the FHR is counted, it should be multiplied by 4 to estimate the FHR, but this is less accurate than listening for a full minute.
  • The standard practice is to listen for the entire 60 seconds every 15 min in first stage and every 5 min in second stage to ensure a precise measurement.

questions.text: A 24 year old primigravida reports to LR at 37 weeks of gestation in early labour. USG shows a single live intrauterine fetus of 36 weeks 5 days gestation FHR 150 bpm, AFI 3 cm, EFW 2.6 kg. Identify the pattern of CTG shown below:
questions.solution:
• The image shows variable decelerations.
  • Variable decelerations are variable in onset, duration and depth.
  • They may occur with contractions or between contractions.
  • Typically, they have an abrupt onset and rapid recovery.
  • Oligohydramnios is associated with more frequent variable decelerations as the amniotic fluid has a protective role on the fetal umbilical cord, and studies have suggested that the use of amnioinfusion may improve the FHR pattern.

Optionwise explanation:

Option a) Early Deceleration

  • The FHR decline mirrors the contraction in timing, creating a "mirror image" where the nadir (lowest point) of the FHR occurs at the peak of the contraction.
  • Early decelerations are usually benign and do not indicate fetal distress. They are seen when fetal head is compressed.

Option b) Late Deceleration

  • Definition: Late decelerations are gradual decreases in FHR that begin after the peak of a uterine contraction and return to baseline after the contraction ends.
  • Cause: They are caused by uteroplacental insufficiency, which results in decreased oxygenation to the fetus.
  • Pattern: The deceleration starts after the contraction has begun, and the lowest point of FHR occurs after the peak of the contraction.
  • Clinical Significance: Late decelerations can be a sign of fetal hypoxia and distress, especially when repetitive and associated with minimal variability or bradycardia. They may require intervention, such as changing maternal position, oxygen administration, or even urgent delivery.

Option d) Sinusoidal Pattern

  • Definition: A sinusoidal pattern is a smooth, wave-like oscillation of the FHR with regular amplitude and frequency, without normal short-term variability.
  • Cause: It is associated with severe fetal anemia, fetal hypoxia, or other serious fetal conditions (e.g., Rh isoimmunization, feto-maternal hemorrhage).
  • Pattern: The pattern has a fixed, undulating waveform that lasts for at least 20 minutes.
  • Clinical Significance: A true sinusoidal pattern is considered an ominous sign of severe fetal distress or anemia and requires immediate evaluation and usually prompt delivery.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

Variable Deceleration

  • Definition: Variable decelerations are abrupt decreases in FHR that vary in timing, duration, and shape, often resembling "V", "U", or "W" patterns.
  • Cause: They are usually caused by umbilical cord compression, which leads to a brief reduction in blood flow to the fetus.
  • Pattern: The onset and recovery of variable decelerations are quick and may or may not be associated with contractions.
  • Clinical Significance: Occasional variable decelerations are common and may not be concerning if the variability remains normal. However, recurrent or severe variable decelerations, especially with slow recovery or reduced variability, may indicate fetal compromise and require intervention.

questions.text: An Rh negative woman presents in labour at 38 weeks of gestation. On examination uterus has mild contractions, P/V examination Cervix 4 cm dilated, 50-60% effaced, vertex at -1 station. ARM done, shows blood stained liquor. FHS drops immediately after ARM. CTG pattern is shown below. Identify:
questions.solution:
• The above image shows sinusoidal pattern.
  • It is a regular, smooth, undulating signal, resembling a sine wave, with an amplitude of 5−15 bpm, and a frequency of 3−5 cycles per minute.
  • This pattern lasts more than 30 minutes, and coincides with absent accelerations.
  • The pathophysiological basis of the sinusoidal pattern is incompletely understood, but it occurs in association with severe fetal anemia, as is found in anti-D alloimmunization, fetal-maternal hemorrhage, twin-to-twin transfusion syndrome, and ruptured vasa previa.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

  • The fresh bleeding after ARM combined with sudden drop in fetal heart rate suggests ruptured vasa previa with subsequent sinusoidal pattern on CTG.

questions.text: Saltatory pattern on CTG (as shown below) is seen when beat-to-beat variability is more than:
questions.solution:
• The above CTG depicts a saltatory pattern. Increased Variability (Saltatory Pattern) refers to a bandwidth value (beat-to-beat variability) exceeding 25 bpm lasting more than 30 minutes.
  • The pathophysiology of this pattern is incompletely understood, but it may be seen linked with recurrent decelerations, when hypoxia/acidosis evolves very rapidly.
  • It is presumed to be caused by fetal autonomic instability/hyperactivity.
  • Intervention may be required sooner if this pattern is seen during the second stage or during decelerations.
  • A saltatory pattern for more than 30 minutes may indicate hypoxia even without decelerations.

KEY TAKE AWAY:

Reference: RCOG Intrapartum Fetal Monitoring Guidelines 2018

choices.text: HIV, hepatitis B or C, herpes are contraindications to FBS
FBS is less likely to be successful when the cervical dilatation is <3 cm
The threshold for intervention is a pH of 7.30 or less when immediate delivery is indicated
FBS is best avoided in fetal bleeding disorders such as haemophilia

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct regarding fetal scalp sampling (FBS) except:
questions.solution:
The threshold for intervention in fetal scalp sampling is typically a pH of 7.20 or less, not 7.30. A pH of 7.20 or below indicates significant fetal acidemia, which usually warrants immediate delivery to prevent further fetal compromise.

Optionwise explanations:

a. HIV, hepatitis B or C, herpes are contraindications to FBS

  • This is due to the risk of transmitting infections from the mother to the fetus during the procedure.

b. FBS is less likely to be successful when the cervical dilatation is <3 cm

  • Adequate cervical dilation is generally required to access the fetal scalp effectively, and less dilation makes the procedure more difficult and less likely to be successful.

d. FBS is best avoided in fetal bleeding disorders such as haemophilia

  • due to the increased risk of bleeding complications.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

  • The threshold for intervention is a pH of 7.20 or less when immediate delivery is indicated.
  • A pH between 7.21 and 7.25 requires closer observation of the CTG trace and repeat FBS within 30 minutes and a drop in pH indicates delivery.
  • If the pH is >7.25 based on CTG abnormalities persist for over one hour or worsen (decelerations getting deeper and wider and an increase in baseline rate or reduction of baseline variability), a repeat FBS should be performed after a suitable interval.

questions.text: Fetal head compression in first or second stage of labour usually leads to this type of deceleration. Identify in the CTG below:
questions.solution:
• Early decelerations are 'mirror images' of contractions and are associated with head compression in the late first and second stages of labour.
  • There is a slow reduction in FHR as the intensity of contraction increases - the lowest FHR or nadir of the deceleration is at the peak or acme of the contraction. There is slow recovery of the FHR to the baseline rate as the contraction abates and returns to the baseline.
  • Since they are 'uniform' decelerations and are reflective of head compression causing vagal stimulation they should be seen only in the late first stage or second stage of labour.
  • Early decelerations are not due to hypoxia and generally they do not decelerate >40 bpm below the baseline rate.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

Early deceleration are managed by making patient lie in left lateral position.

questions.text: A 25 year old primigravida presents at 41 weeks of gestation with labour pains. On examination, uterus shows 3 contractions, each lasting for 25-30 seconds over a period of 10 minutes. On P/V examination, Cervix 3 cm dilated, 30-40% effaced, membranes intact. CTG tracing shown below. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Postdated pregnancy with late decelerations in early labour with intact membranes, next step is to perform an ARM to look for presence of meconium.

  • The above image shows late decelerations.
  • Late decelerations start towards the end or soon after the contraction peaks and the rate does not recover until well after the contraction has ceased. There is a lag of greater than 20 seconds before the onset of the contraction and that of the deceleration.
  • When blood flow and oxygen supply to the intervillous space are critically reduced the FHR slows – an effect mediated via chemoreceptors.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

Various decelerations:-

questions.text: Which of the following is the first to disappear in Biophysical profile (BPP)?
questions.solution:
Fetal breathing is the last to appear & the first to disappear.

BIOPHYSICAL PROFILE / MANNING SCORE

It includes both acute markers of fetal status (fetal heart rate reactivity [FHR-R], fetal breathing [FB] movements, fetal gross body movements [FM], and fetal tone [FT]) and some chronic markers of the fetal and intrauterine condition (amniotic fluid volume [AFV].

FM allegedly develops after FT (at 9 weeks), then FB (at 20-21 weeks).

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

Acronym for BPP --- Remember as "BATMaN"

Tone, Breathing, Movements, AFI & NST

The first activity to appear is FT, at about 7.5-8.5 weeks, is also presumably the last activity to disappear with progressively worsening hypoxia.

Reference: RCOG Intrapartum Fetal Monitoring Guidelines 2018

choices.text: It is formed by joining of three sutures in the midplane
The floor is membranous and it becomes ossified approximately 18 months after birth
Its anteroposterior and transverse diameters measure approximately 3 cm each
It facilitates moulding of the head

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding anterior fontanelle?
questions.solution:
Option (a) is false because anterior fontanel is formed by joining of the four sutures (& not three) in the midplane. The sutures are anteriorly frontal, posteriorly sagittal and on either side, coronal.

The shape is like a diamond.

Option (b) is true. The floor is membranous and it becomes ossified 18 months after birth.

Option (c) is true. Its anteroposterior and transverse diameters measure approximately 3 cm each.

KEY TAKE AWAY :-

Age of closure of fontanalles:-

  • Its palpation through internal examination denotes the degree of flexion of the head.
  • It facilitates molding of the head. (Option d is also true)
  • As it remains membranous long after birth, it helps in accommodating the marked brain growth; the brain becoming almost double its size during the first year of life.
  • Palpation of the floor reflects intracranial status-depressed in dehydration, elevated in raised intracranial tension.
  • Collection of blood and exchange transfusion, on rare occasion, can be performed through it via the superior longitudinal sinus.
  • Cerebrospinal fluid can be drawn, although rarely, through the angle of the anterior fontanelle from the lateral ventricle.

questions.text: A 30 year old G4P3L3 woman presents to LR at 38 weeks of gestation in labour. The obstetrician assesses the case & identifies a brow presentation. Which of the following is the presenting diameter of the fetal skull in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Mentovertical is the presenting diameter in brow presentation (see the table below)

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

questions.text: Which of the following is the smallest transverse diameter of fetal skull?
questions.solution:
The transverse diameters which are concerned in the mechanism of labor are:

Option a) Biparietal diameter-9.5 cm: It extends between two parietal eminences. Whatever may be the position of the head, this diameter nearly always engages.

Option b) Bitemporal diameter-8 cm: It is the distance between the anteroinferior ends of the coronal suture.

Option c) Bimastoid diameter-7.5 cm: It is the distance between the tips of the mastoid processes. The diameter is incompressible and it is impossible to reduce the length of the bimastoid diameter by obstetrical operation.

Option d) Super-subparietal-8.5 cm: It extends from a point placed below one parietal eminence to a point placed above the other parietal eminence of the opposite side.

Hence option (c) is correct.

questions.text: Which of the following is the shortest anteroposterior diameter of the pelvic inlet?
questions.solution:
Obstetric conjugate is the shortest AP diameter of the pelvic inlet.

Option a) True conjugate/Anatomical conjugate/Conjugate vera: It is the distance between the midpoint of the sacral promontory to the inner margin of the upper border of symphysis pubis. It measures 11 cm

Option b) Obstetric conjugate: It is the distance between the midpoint of the sacral promontory to prominent bony projection in the midline on the inner surface of the symphysis pubis. The point is somewhat below its upper border. It is the shortest anteroposterior diameter in the anteroposterior plane of the inlet. It measures 10 cm.

Option c) Diagonal conjugate: It is the distance between the lower border of symphysis pubis to the midpoint on the sacral promontory. It measures 12 cm. It is measured clinically during pelvic assessment in late pregnancy or in labor.

Option d) Sacrocotyloid diameter: It is measured from the sacroiliac joint (where the sacrum meets the ilium) to the opposite iliopectineal eminence (the bony prominence on the pubic bone). The normal sacrocotyloid diameter is typically 9 to 9.5 cm.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

choices.text: The woman is stockily built with bull neck, broad shoulders and short thighs
Pelvis is of the anrthropoid type
There is increased incidence of pre-eclampsia and a tendency for Postmaturity

questions.text: All of the following statements are correct regarding dystocia dystrophia syndrome, except:
questions.solution:
In dystocia dystrophia syndrome is of the android type & not anthropoid.

Dystocia dystrophia syndrome

This syndrome is characterized by the following features:

  • The patient is stockily built with bull neck, broad shoulders and short thighs. (Option a is true)
  • She is obese with a male distribution of hairs.
  • They are usually subfertile (Option b is true), having dysmenorrhea, oligomenorrhea or irregular periods.
  • There is increased incidence of pre-eclampsia and a tendency for Postmaturity (option d is true).
  • Pelvis is of the android Occipito-posterior position is common.
  • During labor, inertia is common and there is a tendency for deep transverse arrest or outlet dystocia leading to either increased incidence of difficult instrumental delivery or Caesarean section.
  • There is a chance of lactation failure.

KEY TAKE AWAY :-

Dystocia dystrophia syndrome has features of android pelvis, stockily built, subfertile.

questions.text: Identify this method used in the delivery of aftercoming head of breech:
questions.solution:
Option a is correct.

Option b Pinard's method is used to deliver extended legs in breech

Option c Piper's forceps is used to deliver aftercoming head of breech

Option d Lovset's maneuver is used to deliver extended arms in breech.

OTHER MANOEUVEERS:


KEY TAKE AWAY:-

Burns-Marshall method

  • The baby is allowed to hang by its own weight.
  • The assistant is asked to give suprapubic pressure with the flat of hand in a downward and backward direction, the pressure is to be exerted more toward the sinciput. The aim is to promote flexion of the head so that favorable diameter is presented to the pelvic cavity.
  • When the nape of the neck is visible under the pubic arch, the baby is grasped by the ankles with a finger in between the two. Maintaining a steady traction and forming a wide arc of a circle, the trunk is swung in upward and forward direction (as shown in the figure).
  • Meanwhile, with the left hand to guard the perineum, slipping the perineum off successively the face and brow.
  • When the mouth is cleared off the vulva, there should be no hurry. Mucus of the mouth and pharynx is cleared by mucus sucker.
  • The trunk is depressed to deliver rest of the head.

questions.text: A 32 year old multigravida at 37 weeks' gestation arrives at LR with cord prolapse. Which of the following malpresentations is most commonly associated with cord prolapse?
questions.solution:
ETIOLOGY OF CORD PROLAPSE: Anything which interferes with perfect adaptation of the presenting part to the lower uterine segment, disturbing the ball valve action may favor cord prolapse. Too often, more than one factor operates.

The following are the associated factors:

  1. Malpresentations-the most common being transverse (5-10%) and breech (3%) -FOOTLING(max)>KNEE>FLEXED/COMPLETE BREECH>FRANK BREEECH.9(least)
  2. Contracted pelvis
  3. Prematurity
  4. Twins
  5. Hydramnios
  6. Placental factor- minor degree placenta previa with marginal insertion of the cord or long cord
  7. Iatrogenic-low rupture of the membranes, manual rotation of the head, ECV, IPV

Key TAKE AWAY:-

Transverse lie is associated with a risk of cord prolapse as high as 20%.

Overt cord prolapse occurs in more than 1% breech deliveries:

  • 0.5% cephalic and frank breech presentations.
  • 5% complete breech.
  • 15% footling breech.

choices.text: Upper segment of the uterus contracts more strongly and for a longer time than the lower segment
Pacemaker of the uterine contractions is situated in the region of the tubal ostia
Intrauterine pressure is raised to 110-120 mm Hg during first stage and about 40-50 mm Hg in second stage of labour during contractions

questions.text: Identify the incorrect statement regarding uterine contractions in labour:
questions.solution:
UTERINE CONTRACTIONS IN LABOR

Throughout pregnancy there is irregular involuntary spasmodic uterine contractions which are painless (Braxton Hicks) and have no effect on dilatation of the cervix.

The character of the contractions changes with the onset of labour:

  • There is fundal dominance of contractions (Option a) that diminish gradually in duration and intensity through midzone down to lower segment.
  • The upper segment of the uterus contracts more strongly (Option b) and for a longer time than the lower part.
  • The pacemaker of the uterine contractions is situated in the region of the tubal ostia (Option c) from where waves of contractions spread downward
  • Option d) Intrauterine pressure is raised to 40-50 mm Hg during first stage and about 100-120 mm Hg in second stage of labor during contractions. In spite of diminished pain in third stage, the intrauterine pressure is probably the same as that in the second stage.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

Enough intrauterine pressure would be more in 2nd stage as compared to 1st stage of labour

questions.text: A 25 year young G1P0 woman comes to Labour Room with complaints of lower abdominal pain since past 6 hours. On per vaginal examination, she is found to have a cervical dilatation of 5 cm, effacement of 50-60%, membranes intact, and station of presenting part at -2. She demands obstetric analgesia, for which the following procedure is performed & drug is delivered to the space shown. Which spinal segments does this form of obstetric analgesia intends to block at this point in her laboring process?
questions.solution:
The first stage of labor requires a sensory block from T10 to L1. During the second stage of labor and for operative vaginal delivery, a sensory block of S2 - S4 is usually adequate to cover pain from perineal stretching and/or instrumentation. Analgesic options include continuous lumbar epidural analgesia, combined spinal-epidural, continuous spinal analgesia, and other blocks such as pudendal and paracervical blocks. Here epidural analgesia is shown in the picture which intends to block spinal segments T10 to L1, hence option b is correct.

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

  • Epidural block is best block for painless labor
  • At T10 level
  • Sensory + Sympathetic + No motor block
  • Shortens 1st stage and prolongs 2nd stage of labour
  • Do not increase chance of LSCS

questions.text: A 30 year old G2POA1 woman comes to Labour Room with complaints of lower abdominal pain since 8 hours, leaking per vaginum since 4hours. On per vaginal examination she has a cervical dilatation of 6 cm, cervical length of 1 cm, ruptured membranes with clear liquor, station of vertex at 0 and regular uterine contractions. In a duration of 3 hours, she became fully dilated and then in another 2 hours, head was seen crowning at the perineum. Which of the following manoeuvres is being performed (as shown in the figure) for the delivery of head in these circumstances?
questions.solution:
Modified Ritgen Maneuver is correct as it is used in controlled delivery of head.

Option b Prague maneuver is used for Occipitoposterior position.

Option c Lovset maneuver is for delivery of extended arms in breech.

Option d MSV maneuver is to deliver aftercoming head of breech.

  • When the head distends the vulva and perineum enough to open the vaginal introitus to a diameter of 5 cm or more, a gloved hand may be used to support the perineum. The other hand is used to guide and control the fetal head to deliver the smallest head diameter through the introitus and to avoid expulsive delivery.
  • Slow delivery of the head may decrease lacerations. Overall, bracing the perineum lowers rates of anal sphincter injury compared with a "hands off" approach to delivery.
  • Alternatively, if expulsive efforts are inadequate or expeditious delivery is needed, the modified Ritgen maneuver may be employed or an episiotomy cut.
  • With the modified maneuver, gloved fingers beneath a draped towel exert forward pressure on the fetal chin through the perineum just in front of the coccyx (as shown in the figure).

KEY TAKE AWAY:-

MSV maneuver

Loveset Maneuver

Prague maneuver

questions.text: A low level (< 0.4 MoM) of which of the following first trimester markers should be considered a major risk factor for delivery of SGA (small for gestational age) neonate?
questions.solution:
A low level (< 0.4 MoM) of the first trimester marker PAPP–A (Pregnancy Associated Plasma Protein A) should be considered a major risk factor for delivery of SGA neonate.

RCOG Algorithm for diagnosis of FGR follows:

KEY TAKEAWAY-

  • A low level (< 0.4 MoM) of PAPP-A (Pregnancy Associated Plasma Protein A) should be considered a major risk factor for delivery of SGA neonate.
  • If risk factor for preeclampsia are present Low dose Aspirin at <16 weeks should be started

questions.text: A 19 year old primigravida presents to ANC OPD at 26 weeks of gestation. She belongs to a lower socioeconomic status. On obstetric examination, the fundal height lags behind the gestational age by 4 weeks. She has a dating scan which shows correspondence to period of amenorrhoea. The obstetrician asks the sonologist to specifically check one fetal biometry parameter in the scan. Which of the following biometric parameters is most sensitive for diagnosing fetal growth restriction?
questions.solution:
AC is the most sensitive biometric parameter for diagnosing FGR. It reflects liver size and fat deposition, which are directly affected by nutrient supply from the placenta. In cases of growth restriction, abdominal circumference is the first parameter to lag behind.

Optionwise explanation:

a. Biparietal Diameter (BPD)

  • Sensitivity for FGR: Low.
  • Explanation: BPD measures the width of the fetal head and is less reliable for diagnosing fetal growth restriction (FGR), especially in the later stages of pregnancy, because head growth is typically preserved in cases of asymmetric growth restriction.

b. Transcerebellar Diameter

  • Sensitivity for FGR: Low.
  • Explanation: This measures the width of the cerebellum and is used in assessing fetal growth during early pregnancy but is not typically sensitive for FGR in the third trimester.

c. Head Circumference (HC)

  • Sensitivity for FGR: Moderate.
  • Explanation: HC is useful in some cases but is not as sensitive as abdominal circumference. In cases of asymmetric growth restriction, the head may continue growing normally while the rest of the body lags behind.

KEY TAKEAWAY-.

  • Sonographic predictive values that are commonly used are: Head circumference (HC) and abdominal circumference (AC) ratio.
  • In a normally growing fetus the HC/AC ratio exceeds 1.0 before 32 weeks. It is approximately 1.0 at 32 to 34 weeks. After 34 weeks, it falls below 1.0.
  • If the fetus is affected by asymmetric IUGR, the HC remains larger. The HC/AC is then elevated.
  • In symmetric IUGR, both the HC and AC are reduced. The HC/AC ratio remains normal. Using HC/AC ratio, 85% of IUGR fetuses are detected.

Abdominal Circumference (AC) is the single most sensitive parameter to detect IUGR Serial measurements of AC and estimation of fetal weight are more diagnostic to fetal growth restriction.

questions.text: Cut off for fetal abdominal circumference (AC) or estimated fetal weight (EFW) to diagnose FGR:
questions.solution:
Currently, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists and the Society for Maternal-Fetal Medicine (2020) recommend defining FGR as either an EFW <10th percentile for gestational age or AC < 10th percentile for gestational age.

Optionwise explanation:

a. < 5th centile

  • Explanation: While this centile may indicate severe fetal growth restriction (FGR), the commonly accepted threshold for diagnosing FGR is a higher cutoff to capture more

c. < 15th centile

  • Explanation: This is above the standard diagnostic cutoff for FGR, and although it may indicate concern, it is not the standard criterion for FGR diagnosis.

d. < 20th centile

  • Explanation: Similar to the 15th centile, this would suggest that the fetus is smaller than average but does not meet the diagnostic criteria for FGR.

KEY TAKEAWAY- The cutoff of < 10th centile (option b) is the accepted standard for diagnosing fetal growth restriction (FGR).

questions.text: When using two measurements of AC or EFW to estimate growth velocity, the measurements should be at least how many weeks apart to minimize false-positive rates for diagnosing FGR?
questions.solution:
A 3-week interval between two measurements of abdominal circumference (AC) or estimated fetal weight (EFW) is optimal for assessing growth velocity. This minimizes false-positive rates for diagnosing FGR, as it allows sufficient time for meaningful growth changes to be detected.

Optionwise explanation:

a. 1 week

  • Explanation: Measuring fetal growth over such a short interval is unlikely to accurately reflect growth velocity, as normal fluctuations and measurement errors could lead to false positives.

b. 2 weeks

  • Explanation: While a 2-week interval may provide more information than a 1-week interval, it is still considered too short to reliably estimate true growth velocity, increasing the risk of false positives.

d. 4 weeks

  • Explanation: Although a longer interval of 4 weeks could also be used, it may delay the diagnosis and timely intervention for FGR, potentially compromising fetal health.

KEY TAKEAWAY-

  • Serial assessments of fetal biometry can identify the worsening in growth velocity in fetuses diagnosed as SGA.
  • To estimate growth velocity measurements should be used at minimum of 3 weeks apart in order to minimize the false positive rate.

questions.text: Identify the umbilical artery Doppler flow pattern:
questions.solution:
• Umbilical artery Doppler flow studies are central to the evaluation and management of the fetus with growth restriction
  • Specifically, initially increased impedance to flow in the umbilical artery may progress to absent end-diastolic flow and then reversed end diastolic flow.
  • This negative progression correlates with hypoxia, acidosis, and fetal death.
  • Because of these findings, the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (2021) and Society for Maternal-Fetal Medicine (2020) recommend serial umbilical artery Doppler studies in the management of FGR.

KEY TAKEAWAY -FIGURE shows Doppler velocity waveforms.

  1. Normal waveform with normal S/D ratio.
  2. Increased impedance to flow with abnormally elevated S/D ratio.
  3. Absent end-diastolic flow.
  4. Reversed end-diastolic flow

questions.text: A 31 week fetus is growth restricted, has oligohydramnios and an abnormal calvarium. Which anti-hypertensive agent taken by the mother in the antenatal period may have caused this problem?
questions.solution:
ACE inhibitor, it is known to cause severe fetal complications when used in pregnancy, particularly in the later trimesters.

  • Lisinopril may result in angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE)- inhibitor fetopathy.
  • Normal renal development depends on the fetal renin angiotensin system.
  • ACE-inhibitor medication may cause fetal hypotension and renal hypoperfusion, with subsequent ischemia and anuria.
  • Reduced perfusion can result in fetal-growth restriction and calvarium maldevelopment, and oligohydramnios may lead to pulmonary hypoplasia and limb contractures.

Optionwise explanation:

  1. Verapamil: This is a calcium channel blocker, which is generally safe during pregnancy. It does not cause the mentioned fetal abnormalities.
  2. Nifedipine: Another calcium channel blocker commonly used to treat hypertension in pregnancy. It is not associated with fetal growth restriction, oligohydramnios, or abnormal calvarium.
  3. Methyldopa: A centrally acting alpha-2 agonist that is commonly used for managing hypertension in pregnancy and is considered safe. It does not lead to the described fetal issues.

KEY TAKEAWAY- some of drugs contraindicated in pregnancy

ACE inhibitors

ARB blockers

Diuretics

choices.text: Perinatal morbidity & mortality is high as compared to late onset FGR
Cerebral blood flow redistribution is the key finding on doppler

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding early-onset FGR?
questions.solution:
Cerebral blood flow redistribution is more commonly associated with late-onset fetal growth restriction (FGR) rather than early-onset FGR.

In early-onset FGR, the Doppler findings often include changes in the umbilical artery and middle cerebral artery but do not prominently feature redistribution.

Optionwise explanation:

  1. Gestational age at manifestation <32 weeks: This statement is correct. Early-onset FGR typically manifests before 32 weeks of gestation.
  2. Perinatal morbidity & mortality is high as compared to late onset FGR: This statement is also correct. Early-onset FGR is associated with higher rates of perinatal complications and mortality compared to late-onset FGR.
  3. Usually associated with preeclampsia: This statement is correct. Early-onset FGR is frequently linked to maternal conditions like preeclampsia, which can impair placental blood flow and fetal growth.

KEY TAKEAWAY- D/D between Early & Late-onset FGR

Reference: FOGSI GCPR on Fetal Growth Disorders
